The art of the game is cute and the entire aesthetic is pleasant. However, the game‚Äôs potential to be very calming is undercut by the frustrating fact that it is difficult to play a game where just tapping on an object can do way too many things, and accidentally tapping on the wrong thing annoyingly diverts the game. It would be much better if there were, say, separate modes for different actions. For instance, if I wanted to move the plants on my farm around, I could press a button and enter a separate mode to do so, and then afterwards press that button again to exit the mode. That way, when I‚Äôm collecting the harvest from my plants, I don‚Äôt have to worry about accidentally moving them around. I also wouldn‚Äôt have to worry about the little pet standing too near an object or plant so that when I feed it, the game thinks I‚Äôm trying to move that object and the pet disappears.

It‚Äôs also very frustrating that the game is set up mostly two-dimensionally and yet objects and plants can block one another! I want to be able to put rings of flowers around my trees, but I can‚Äôt because I won‚Äôt be able to harvest the flowers that I put behind the trees‚Äînot without the game thinking that I‚Äôm trying to move the trees around. 

Otherwise, the game is simple and fun. It just needs more work to make its interface more playable and less aggravating.

I‚Äôve been using Tome since the beta days and was genuinely excited at first. It felt like the perfect space for book lovers. The concept was fresh, and the customization options were a fun way to make the app your own. It really seemed like it could be a thriving, supportive community.

But honestly, if I were a new user coming in now, I‚Äôd feel completely lost. The layout is congested, confusing, and lacks any real guidance. Nothing is intuitive, and with how the algorithm and community function, it feels nearly impossible for new users to be seen. Unless you‚Äôre already part of the in-crowd, you disappear into the noise.

I was deeply invested. I subscribed, became a Tome Keeper, and actively participated because I had faith in the product and believed in its potential. But over time, that faith turned into disappointment.

The app often feels like posting into the void unless you‚Äôre part of a tight-knit group. The badge system is tied to tokens, which you either have to buy with real money or receive as a gift from someone who spent their own. Tokens are then used to buy profile badges that are mostly tied to obscure inside jokes or designed for specific cliques. As a subscriber, you receive a monthly allowance of 1400 tokens, but beyond buying badges, I honestly don‚Äôt know what the point of them is. The system feels more cosmetic than meaningful.

People can also gift tokens by reacting to posts with a bread emoji‚Äîyet another inside joke that isn‚Äôt explained anywhere in the app. It‚Äôs a system that largely benefits users already plugged into the culture, especially those active in the Discord.

A lot of the app‚Äôs culture and inside jokes come from the Tome Discord. While it includes various channels, I felt its original purpose was to report bugs, receive updates, and give feedback. But now it primarily reinforces the exclusivity already present on the platform. Some users are so involved in maintaining their presence that they update their profiles multiple times a day to match ongoing jokes. That level of effort is a lot, and it only seems to pay off if you‚Äôre already known.

Tome also runs monthly profile contests that require a huge amount of time and design effort. In theory, they‚Äôre creative and fun. In practice, the winners almost always come from the same social circles. Votes are cast by other users, but the algorithm boosts the same few popular accounts - making it hard for new or outside voices to be seen. It feels more like a popularity contest than a celebration of creativity.

Users are encouraged to promote Tome on their social platforms, but there‚Äôs no real reward. Even ambassadors, who are given access to a private Discord channel, get nothing more than a sparkle emoji visible only to other ambassadors. It often feels like a lot of unpaid labor for superficial recognition.

You also can‚Äôt actually track your reads in a structured way. There‚Äôs no reading log, goal setting, or progress tracking. Instead, you can make a subpage to post your current reads, but it‚Äôs more like blogging than actual reading organization. Thoughtful reviews are often ignored, while most engagement goes to posts about shadow daddies or thirsting over app creators. It feels more like a fandom-heavy Tumblr than a space for genuine book connection.

Tome had a great idea, and I respect the original vision. But the current version feels performative, cliquish, and overwhelmingly busy. It doesn‚Äôt prioritize the reader experience‚Äîand definitely not the new reader experience. I‚Äôm giving it 2 stars for the concept and potential, but it‚Äôs not the inclusive or functional book space I hoped it would be.
